Purpose/Aim

This guideline is intended to assist healthcare professionals involved in the care of patients who are at risk of and/or suffer from a major haemorrhage. These are to be used only when it is clear that the patient is not to receive cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) due to advanced, untreatable diagnosis, and the goal of management of the event must be to minimize anxiety, ease suffering and ensure death with dignity providing a calm, reassuring and caring atmosphere.
Introduction

Catastrophic terminal bleeding can be rapid and produce massive blood loss in patients who are not appropriate for active treatment (such as radiotherapy or endovascular interventions). Catastrophic bleeding can lead to the death of the patient within minutes of onset. Patients experiencing terminal events will need rapid effective management to minimise the distress of their imminent death. Support will also be required for relatives and staff.
Scope
All medical and nursing staff who are involved with palliative care patients who are at a high risk of a catastrophic bleed.
This policy excludes patients who are under 18 years of age.
Definitions

table_items.text: Patients with tumours close to major arteries or airways, e.g. central lung tumours, head and neck tumours, liver tumours, fungating tumours. Haematology patients – refractory leukaemia and myeloproliferative disorders. Palliative patients at risk of upper gastrointestinal bleeds, e.g. oesophageal varices or with clotting disorders (including chronic liver disease) or signs of partial airway obstruction e.g. stridor or refractory wheeze.

data.text: Preparation of Palliative Patients who are at a High Risk of a
catastrophic bleed
High risk patients:
Patients with tumours close to major arteries or airways, e.g. central lung tumours, head and neck tumours, liver tumours, fungating tumours.
Haematology patients – refractory leukaemia and myeloproliferative disorders.

Palliative patients at risk of upper gastrointestinal bleeds, e.g. oesophageal varices or with clotting disorders (including chronic liver disease) or signs of partial airway obstruction e.g. stridor or refractory wheeze.
Establish the goals of treatment
5.2.1 Clarify and document resuscitation status as per hospital policy.

5.2.2 Discuss with the patient and family as appropriate (balance the need for patients and relatives to be aware of the risk versus the reality that catastrophic haemorrhages and airway obstruction are rare).

5.2.3 Allow patients/families the opportunity to discuss any worries or concerns they may have about the mode of death. (It may also be advisable to discuss the risk of major haemorrhage and any special circumstances to consider e.g. presence of children in the room during a bleed etc).
5.2.4 Consider ceasing anticoagulant and anti-inflammatory medications.
Preparation
5.3.1 Chart appropriate medication (refer to section 9.4).
5.3.2 Ensure all nurses and healthcare professionals involved in looking after the patient are aware of the risk and the policy.
5.3.3 Consider if the patient should be moved to a single room.
5.3.4 Ensure that appropriate equipment is readily available:
If possible, dark coloured towels or blankets;
Personal Protection Equipment (gloves, goggles, aprons, waste bags);
Suction;
Oxygen.
In the Event of Catastrophic Terminal Haemorrhage

It is important to provide a calm, reassuring and caring environment for the patient and family/carers. The patient should not be left alone during a catastrophic bleed. In some cases, death is rapid and staff comfort is the only support that the patient and family have during this period.
Issuing an emergency call may still be appropriate to ensure enough staff are available to organise medications and patient comfort.
For patients who are experiencing a catastrophic haemorrhage, placing the patient in a lateral decubitus position toward the site of bleeding may reduce the risk of aspiration and improve comfort.
Apply pressure to bleeding site if possible, and/or cover bleeding with towels.
Administer appropriate medications (refer to section 9), if staffing allows.
Provide privacy and protect other patients by drawing curtains, moving other patients from the room (if patient not already in a side room).
Medications
In many cases, the patient will lose consciousness before medications can be administered, hence staying and comforting the patient is the most important treatment to be offered.
Midazolam relieves anxiety and the distress of a large volume bleed and/or the sensation of suffocation.
If the patient survives then midazolam is an amnestic agent and the patient should have little memory of the event.

Morphine is usually not beneficial for haemorrhage alone, but may be appropriate if the episode is prolonged and associated with pain or dyspnoea. Morphine can help the discomfort associated with airway obstruction.
So that these medications can be readily given if appropriate, inpatients at a high risk of a catastrophic bleed should have the following prescribed in the stat section of the treatment chart:
“For use in catastrophic bleed only”
Midazolam10mg/2ml injection: 5 – 10mg* SC/IM;
Morphine injection 10mg* SC (or Oxycodone injection 5mg SC);
*If a patient is on regular opioids, prescribe patients usual prn dose if higher.
7.4.1  For community patients, prescribe on the community drug chart.
Repeat doses can be given after 5 to 10 minutes if required. For ward patients, repeat doses will need to be prescribed by the ward doctor in attendance.

On wards and units which frequently have palliative patients at a high risk of a catastrophic bleed (e.g. ENT, oncology wards), it may be appropriate to store an ampoule of midazolam and morphine in an emergency box inside the controlled drugs cupboard which can be quickly brought to the patient's bedside in the event of a bleed. For further details, refer to appendix
Discharging Patients who are at High Risk of a Catastrophic Bleed
It is important to have discussed with the patient and their relatives/carers what to expect and how to deal with a catastrophic bleed should this occur at home.
A copy of the letter (appendix 1) should be given to the patient to take home which gives instructions to other healthcare professionals taking care of the patient.

Depending on the patient's circumstances, it may be appropriate to prescribe and supply the patient with an ampoule of midazolam 10mg/2ml and/or an ampoule of Morphine 10mg/ml (or oxycodone 5mg injection) to enable any healthcare professional who may be present to give if appropriate at the time of the bleed. Inform the patient/carers that these are anticipatory medications to be used by healthcare professionals only and to be returned to a chemist if no longer required.

Depending on the patient's circumstances (e.g. patients condition and home situation), consider issuing a buccal midazolam (Buccolam) which the patients relatives/carers could administer if a healthcare professional is not present. (consider only if buccal administration is appropriate and if relatives/carers are capable and understand when this would be appropriate to use).
Training Requirements
All healthcare professionals looking after a palliative patient who is at a high risk of a catastrophic bleed should be familiar with this guideline.
All medical and nursing staff are to ensure that their knowledge, competencies and skills are up to date.
(Refer to 08092 Mandatory Training Policy)
Monitoring and Audit
Any risks or incidents, including near-misses, or any breaches of compliance with this policy must be recorded on a Datix and investigated appropriately.
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Appendix 2: Use of an emergency drug box for inpatients at risk of catastrophic bleed
As the patient may lose consciousness before the medications can be administered, staying and comforting the patient is the most important treatment to be offered.

If another member of staff is available, then medications such as midazolam and morphine may be considered to help ease the distress of the patient. These medications should be prescribed in anticipation in patients at risk of a catastrophic bleed. To reduce the time delay in obtaining these medications, it may be appropriate to keep an ampoule of the medications in an emergency box stored in the controlled drugs (CD) cupboard which can be taken to the patient's bedside in an emergency.
Creating an emergency drug box
- The box should be plastic (or similar) with a closable lid and take up minimal room in the CD Cupboard.
- The box should be clearly labelled “for use in a catastrophic bleed”.
- The box should be furnished so the ampoules are held firm and not easily broken.
- The contents of the box should be checked daily as part of the daily CD check and ampoules close to expiry should be reported to pharmacy.
- The contents should include:
1 ampoule of midazolam 10mg/2ml injection
1 ampoule of morphine 10mg/ml injection
Needles/syringes as necessary
Issuing ampoules to the emergency box from the CD cupboard

When an ampoule (either midazolam or morphine) needs to be issued to an emergency box (either to replace a used ampoule or replace an expired ampoule) then the following entry should be made in the CD register on the appropriate page for that drug.
Using an ampoule from the emergency box
If an ampoule in the emergency box is used, this should be recorded in the CD register at the earliest opportunity.
- The entry should be made on the “Emergency Box – midazolam” (or morphine) page as appropriate.
- The date used and patients name should be entered into the appropriate columns.
- The dose administered should be entered and signed by the person who gave the
injection and signed by the witness.
- Any of the contents that were destroyed should be entered and signed by the responsible person and the witness.
- The ampoule should be replaced in the emergency box as above.
